author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: This May Be the Most Important Thing Happening in the World Today
description: Fewer children are starving, fewer moms are dying and terrible diseases are retreating.
content: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — One of the misimpressions people have about the world is that it’s going to hell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli, Victoria Kim, Erin Mendell and Isabella Kwai
title: India’s Train Crash: What We Know
description: Three trains were involved in the fatal crash in Odisha State. It was the deadliest such disaster in decades in a country where train travel has grown far safer in recent years.
content: A train crash in eastern India on Friday was the country’s worst rail disaster in two decades, killing more than 280 people and renewing questions about rail safety in a country that has invested heavily in the system in recent years after a long history of deadly crashes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: New Hampshire Man Is Arrested After Threatening to Kill U.S. Senator
description: In a voice mail message, the man told the senator that he was “a dead man walking,” according to federal court documents. He was angry about the blocking of military promotions, prosecutors said.
content: A man from New Hampshire faces up to up to 10 years in prison after threatening to kill a United States senator because he was angry that the senator was “blocking military promotions,” according to federal court documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Texas Governor Signs Bill Banning Transgender Care for Minors
description: The measure makes Texas the largest state to ban transition medical treatment for people under 18.
content: Greg Abbott, the Republican governor of Texas, signed a bill on Friday to ban hormone and puberty blocking treatments, as well as surgeries, for transgender minors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Hill
title: The Exclusive, Elusive World of Real Tennis
description: “If you wanted to design a game that was going to put people off from playing it,” one court tennis enthusiast said, “you would probably design a real tennis court.”
content: Up on the second floor, hidden behind the facade of a tall Haussmann building not far from the Arc de Triomphe, is the Jeu de Paume Club, the only active court tennis club in Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘Doing the Work’ and the Obsession With Superficial Self-Improvement
description: I simply decline.
content: A few weeks ago I noticed that the TikTok algorithm kept serving me videos of 20-somethings speaking directly to camera, admonishing me to “do the work.” They wanted me to know that they were doing the work and that doing the work would eventually turn them into self-actualized beings poised for greater success in life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Fox
title: Isabel Allende Has a Message: History Repeats Itself
description: In her new novel, “The Wind Knows My Name,” the prolific author introduces characters who narrowly survive real-life events.
content: If the measure of a civilization is the way in which it cares for its most vulnerable, by most standards, ours isn’t doing too well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Growing Protests in Serbia Demand Social Changes After Mass Shootings
description: The protests, which have gathered momentum since two massacres in May, are denouncing a “culture of violence” and the increasingly authoritarian rule of the country’s leader.
content: Protests in Serbia over back-to-back mass shootings last month ballooned on Saturday into the biggest street demonstrations in the capital, Belgrade, since demonstrators toppled Slobodan Milosevic as Serbia’s president in 2000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: Larking, Library Sales and Yellow Silk Pajamas
description: An editor recommends old and new books.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Nikola Jokic, an Elusive Superstar, Has a Hold on Denver
description: Jokic, the Nuggets center, may be the best player in the N.B.A., but he avoids the spotlight. Still, in his own way, he has endeared himself to a city hungry for someone to believe in.
content: About two miles from downtown Denver, the yellows, oranges and reds of a spray-painted mural fill the cracked, gray cement wall of a building that houses a temporary employment agency. The mural rises about 20 feet and depicts an expressionless Nikola Jokic next to a much more emotive Jamal Murray, his eyes narrowed and arms extended as though he is wielding a bow and arrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Dan Bilefsky
title: These are some of the deadliest rail disasters in India’s recent history.
description: Friday’s crash is remarkable even in a country with a long history of train deaths.
content: The train crash that killed at least 288 people, and injured hundreds more, in India is remarkable even in a country with a long history of train deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Pochoda
title: What You Don’t Know About Your Neighbors Can Hurt You
description: In “The Whispers,” Ashley Audrain explores the combustibility of secrets and rage among mothers in a small community.
content: The other night at dinner, a friend told me that her debut thriller would be promoted as upmarket women’s fiction. My heart sank. I know that bookstores and sales teams rely on categories, but this one has always rubbed me the wrong way. If women’s fiction is meant to illuminate the ways in which women exist in the world — casting a light on their triumphs, strengths, oppressions and fears — shouldn’t the books in this category also be essential reading for men?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Muzz, a Muslim Dating App, Takes Its Matchmaking on the Road
description: The marriage and dating app, which assists young Muslims in finding “the one,” hosted a singles event in Brooklyn.
content: On a Thursday evening in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, about 250 Muslims gathered in a halal Italian restaurant for a singles dating event. Some of them shied away from cameras, citing privacy concerns, while others said they were afraid of appearing “desperate.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Stumper
description: Proceed with caution through this themeless puzzle by John Westwig.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is John Westwig’s seventh grid for The Times, his third Saturday puzzle in a row and his first construction for us that features span entries, which always bring me joy. These are terrific: a beautiful stack of three across the equator, all with a common trait, and a single, bright debut in the middle of the vertical column that serves as a deadpan revealer of sorts, if one would allow such a thing in a themeless puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Raymer
title: My Father Taught Me the Benefits of Delusion
description: Buried in delusion is the hope that, despite all the odds and evidence to the contrary, things might just go your way.
content: In 2015, at the height of my father’s homelessness, he took me on vacation. By “height,” I mean shelters were a thing of the past. He was living on the street and didn’t have a car, so we took mine. The hot, white Florida sun ran along the corner of the windshield as we drove in a loop around Fort Myers Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Ryan
title: Welcome to CringeTok, Where Being Insufferable Can Be Lucrative
description: On TikTok, cringe comedy creators are gaining large followings and brand deals by impersonating terrible people.
content: During a three-part special examining the crimes of the serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer that aired last November on “Dr. Phil,” Phil McGraw, the host of the daytime talk show, played a TikTok video of a 27-year-old woman named Stanzi Potenza as evidence that true-crime fandom had gone too far. In the video, Ms. Potenza said she was so obsessed with Netflix’s “Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story” that she stayed home from work in diapers to binge the series uninterrupted.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A High Court Held in Low Esteem
description: Readers discuss calls for stronger ethics guidelines for the justices and less partisanship.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni, Sarah Kessler and Ravi Mattu
title: Who Is Liable for A.I. Creations?
description: Tools like ChatGPT could open a new line of questions around tech products and harmful content.
content: A string of challenges to Section 230 — the law that shields online platforms from liability for user-generated content — have failed over the last several weeks. Most recently, the Supreme Court declined on Tuesday to review a suit about exploitative content on Reddit. But the debate over what responsibility tech companies have for harmful content is far from settled — and generative artificial intelligence tools like the ChatGPT chatbot could open a new line of questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: 3 Israeli Soldiers Killed in Rare Attack on Egyptian Border
description: The suspect was identified by the Israeli and Egyptian authorities as an Egyptian security officer. The deadly event may be connected to a thwarted drug smuggling attempt, the Israelis said.
content: A man identified by the Israeli and Egyptian authorities as an Egyptian security officer entered Israeli territory on Saturday and killed three Israeli soldiers in two separate shooting incidents in a remote desert area along the border between the two countries, according to an initial investigation by the Israeli military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: How Did Birds First Take Off?
description: It took 150 million years for feathered dinosaurs to master flight and become the birds we see overhead today.
content: In 1993, “Jurassic Park” helped inspire 9-year-old Stephen Brusatte to become a paleontologist. So Dr. Brusatte was thrilled to advise the producers of last year’s “Jurassic World: Dominion” on what scientists had learned about dinosaurs since he was a child.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: The Dodgers and the Yankees Finally Look Like Themselves
description: Both teams have been winning with smoke and mirrors thanks to injuries. A series against each other in Los Angeles offers a test of just how good they are.
content: The juggernaut franchises faced off in the World Series 11 times between 1941 and 1981. But since then, they had been limited to 16 interleague games against each other heading into this weekend. And the last time they met, the Yankees and the Dodgers didn’t even look the part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: ‘Everything Changed’: The War Arrives on Russians’ Doorstep
description: With cross-border strikes, residents of the Russian region of Belgorod are starting to understand the horrors of war being waged at their doorstep.
content: Over the last five days of May, Ruslan, an English teacher in a Russian town near the Ukrainian border, heard the distinct sound of a multiple rocket launcher strike for the first time. Shelling would begin around 3 a.m., sometimes shaking his house, and continue through the morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What Will Be the Theme of Summer?
description: As summer commences, so do our pronouncements for what it will be like. In branding, as in all things, moderation is key.
content: The last episode of season eight of “Seinfeld” begins with George learning that the Yankees have given him a three-month severance package. He declares that he’s going to live the next three months to the fullest. He’ll read a book “from beginning to end. In that order.” He’ll play Frisbee golf. “This is gonna be my time,” he declares. “Time to taste the fruits and let the juices drip down my chin. I proclaim this: the Summer of George!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Flying Colors
description: Rafael Musa’s Sunday puzzle sets the tone for June.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong and Zixu Wang
title: With Rainbow Flags, 2 Students Test China’s Shrinking L.G.B.T.Q. Space
description: The students at an elite college in China found themselves on a collision course with the authorities amid a crackdown on gay and transgender expression.
content: Karolyn Li still remembers reading the brochure from China’s prestigious Tsinghua University when she was in high school preparing to apply to college. It highlighted a graduate who had co-founded an L.G.B.T.Q. rights group, a suggestion of inclusivity on campus that surprised Ms. Li, who identifies as queer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: MetLife Stadium Gets an N.H.L. Outdoor Doubleheader, of Sorts
description: Over two days in February 2024, the N.F.L. stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. will host the Rangers against the Islanders, and the Devils against the Flyers.
content: Outdoor N.H.L. hockey will make its debut in New Jersey next year when MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford will host a four-team doubleheader of sorts in the league’s so-called Stadium Series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Texas Is Silencing the Will of Millions of Voters
description: It is joining dozens of states that have asserting dominance over cities through a practice known as state pre-emption.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott, Republican of Texas, is expected to sign a bill in the next few days that would make it immeasurably more difficult for cities in the state to govern themselves. The bill would strip cities of the ability to set standards for local workplaces, to ensure civil rights, and to improve their environments, trampling on the rights of voters who elected local officials to do just that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Jackie on My Mind
description: Before she was an iconic first lady, Jackie was a clever “Camera Girl.”
content: WASHINGTON — I think about Jackie Kennedy several times a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
title: India’s Worst Rail Disaster in Decades Convulses Country Dependent on Trains
description: The disaster killed at least 288 people, and a preliminary government report described it as a “three-way accident” involving two passenger trains and an idled cargo train. Officials were investigating possible signal failure.
content: As giant excavators tried to untangle crushed trains on Saturday at the scene of India’s worst rail disaster in decades, a solemn scene was playing out at a small school a few hundred yards away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Coco Gauff Has a Chance to Play the Wise Veteran at the French Open
description: Gauff, now 19 and in her fifth season on the tour, took on Mirra Andreeva, who is 16 and the latest teenager to go on a tear in women’s tennis.
content: Tennis moves fast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Damien Cave and David Pierson
title: U.S. Vows to Continue Patrols Near China and Urges Nuclear Talks
description: Speeches by two top officials illustrated the depth of concern over the rift between the nations. China called it provocation.
content: The United States pressed Beijing on two fronts this weekend, warning both of the near-term risks of military mishaps and of the looming dangers of a nuclear arms rivalry, prompting a vehement accusation from a Chinese general that Washington was stoking confrontation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Farrington
title: Reconsidering the Reputation of a Magnet for Roman Scandal
description: In “Messalina,” Honor Cargill-Martin looks at the limited evidence with empathy, arguing that a notorious empress was also a canny politician.
content: The past is as much a foreign language as a foreign country, full of words and names that have lost their force. Not that long ago, one of the worst insults for a woman was “Messalina,” after the third wife of the Roman emperor Claudius, who was damned by antiquity as a sex-crazed schemer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: As Older TikTok Creators Flourish, Brands Are Signing Them Up
description: No matter what their age or finances, some elder influencers are finding that being on the app can bring them extra cash, or even help them extend their careers.
content: In one of Jenny Krupa’s TikTok videos, her neighbor has been hurt. Ms. Krupa’s concern? She wants to see “if the paramedics are hot.” In another video, she lets a man who ghosted her know she’s TikTok famous — and he “really screwed up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frances Robles and Andre Paultre
title: Vigilante Justice Rises in Haiti and Crime Plummets
description: Civilians have killed at least 160 gang members in Haiti, a human rights group says. Residents say they feel safer, but others worry that it will lead to even more violence.
content: The 14 presumed gang members under arrest were arriving at a police station in Haiti’s capital, when a group of people overpowered the police, rounded up the suspects outside and used gasoline to burn them alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: Our Live-In Super Is Retiring. Should We Hire Another, or Contract It Out?
description: There are services for hire that will fulfill the duties of a building superintendent. Here are the pros and cons.
content: Q: Our long term live-in superintendent of a 50-unit co-op is retiring. Is it necessary to hire another live-in super, or can his responsibilities, which are relatively light, be contracted out?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Why Do We Brand the Summer?
description: Barefoot-Boy Summer? Side Chick Summer? It’s officially the season of out-there predictions for the summer ahead.
content: As trees open their blooms, the predictions come on like an allergy attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: 5 Takeaways From Ron DeSantis’s First Campaign Trip
description: He swung back at Donald Trump. He vowed to vanquish the “woke mob” and turn the country into mega-Florida. He had normal encounters with voters that didn’t become memes.
content: After his unusual, buzzy and ill-fated presidential debut on Twitter last week, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida carried out a far more traditional campaign tour this week, barnstorming Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina to sell himself as the strongest Republican alternative to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Zarroli
title: Why It’s So Hard to Tear Down a Crumbling Highway Nearly Everyone Hates
description: The Interstate 81 viaduct in Syracuse effectively destroyed a Black neighborhood when it was built, and it has been falling apart ever since. But getting rid of it is complicated.
content: These days, hardly anyone in Syracuse sees the hulking Interstate 81 viaduct as anything but a menace, an ugly 1.4-mile overpass that spews noise and pollution and has steadily worsened race relations in the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: How Are Black Americans Progressing?
description: A series from Headway looks back at historical gains for their lessons today.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: What Does Good Psychedelic Therapy Look Like?
description: As MDMA and psilocybin treatments become more mainstream, the therapy component has come under scrutiny. Here’s what’s common in many sessions — and what’s not.
content: Psychedelic therapy is on its way to becoming a mainstream medical treatment for mental health. In 2020 and 2022, residents of Oregon and Colorado voted to legalize the use of psilocybin, the psychoactive ingredient in hallucinogenic mushrooms, and the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve it and MDMA, or Ecstasy, to treat depression and post-traumatic stress disorder by 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Idol’ Creators: ‘This Is Not Going to Be for Everybody’
description: In an interview, the Weeknd, Sam Levinson and Lily-Rose Depp discussed their controversial new HBO drama. “Running headfirst into that fire is what thrills us all,” Levinson said.
content: Last month, the director Sam Levinson and his stars, Abel Tesfaye (a.k.a. the Weeknd) and Lily-Rose Depp, walked into the Lumière Theater at the Cannes Film Festival for the premiere of the first two episodes of their show, “The Idol,” to a standing ovation. The lights hadn’t yet dimmed, but pomp and celebrity fuels Cannes, where ovations are cheap. By the time the screening was over, the amped-up crowd was on its feet again and critics were racing out to fire off some of the most scathing reviews to emerge from this year’s event, with pans studded with barbs like “regressive,” “chauvinistic,” “skin-crawling” and “grim disaster.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 Podcasts to Make Sense of A.I.
description: As the technology’s rapid rise sets off alarms about the risks to society, these shows will help put the boom into context.
content: Over the past year, artificial intelligence has advanced so rapidly that it feels dizzying, and a growing chorus of industry insiders, academics and politicians are sounding the alarm about risks to society. The effects have already been wide-ranging — colleges are struggling to weed out A.I.-generated essays, disinformation researchers are contending with a whole new category of deepfakes, and the threat of A.I. screenwriting is central to the current Hollywood writers’ strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Ben Protess and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Lawyer’s Notes Could Be a Key in the Classified Documents Inquiry
description: M. Evan Corcoran recorded recollections of his legal work last year for Donald Trump. The recording is now in the hands of prosecutors, unnerving some aides to the former president.
content: Turning on his iPhone one day last year, the lawyer M. Evan Corcoran recorded his reflections about a high-profile new job: representing former President Donald J. Trump in an investigation into his handling of classified documents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chantel Tattoli and Marko Risovic
title: Can Old-World Ceramics Survive Modern Tastes?
description: A style of pottery made for centuries in a small Romanian town has recently become a hot commodity.
content: Sorin Giubega’s grandfather was a potter. So was his father. And at 8 years old, Mr. Giubega said, he started to play on a pottery wheel, too.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For This Runner, There Is No Shame in Bringing Up The Rear
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 3, 2023.
content: “You’re slow, buddy. Go home.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: What It Means to Be a Witness Three Generations Later
description: “The Postcard” by Anne Berest makes clear the urgency of third-generation Holocaust storytellers.
content: In 2021, I received an extraordinary message on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: June 3, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 3, 2023.
content: An article on March 16 about a fatal shooting that involved members of the University of Alabama basketball team misidentified the person who was in the car with one player, Brandon Miller, when the shooting occurred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Car Bombing in Russian-Occupied Ukraine Shows Reach of War
description: The blast in the Zaporizhzhia region of southern Ukraine killed a cafe owner who was registered to run in elections seen as an attempt to legitimize Moscow’s illegal annexation of the area.
content: A car bomb killed at least one person on Friday night in Russian-occupied southern Ukraine, according to Ukrainian and Russian officials, highlighting the war’s reach far beyond the front lines as Ukrainian partisans aim to undermine their occupiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to This American Life: The Show of Delights
description: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, and exclusive new shows which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Mark Walker
title: Two Black Members of Native Tribes Were Arrested. The Law Sees Only One as Indian.
description: A Supreme Court ruling barred Oklahoma from prosecuting crimes committed by Native Americans on tribal land, but some Black tribal members are still being prosecuted because they lack “Indian blood.”
content: Early one morning in September 2020, Michael J. Hill called the police after hearing banging on the doors and windows of his home in Okmulgee, Okla. — part of a swath of the state that the Supreme Court had recently ruled to be tribal land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Debt Deal Strategy: Win in the Fine Print
description: The president and his negotiators believe they worked out a deal that allowed Republicans to claim big spending cuts even as the reality was far more modest.
content: Shalanda Young couldn’t sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Signs Fiscal Responsibility Act in End to Debt Limit Crisis
description: Now that the bill is law, the nation will not risk running out of money to pay its obligations for two years.
content: President Biden signed the Fiscal Responsibility Act of 2023 into law on Saturday, ending for now the threat of economic calamity from a default on the nation’s debt and putting limits on spending for two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
title: In Russian Schools, It’s Recite Your ABC’s and ‘Love Your Army’
description: The curriculum for young Russians is increasingly emphasizing patriotism and the heroism of Moscow’s army, while demonizing the West as “gangsters.” One school features a “sniper”-themed math class.
content: A new version of the ABC’s in Russia’s Far East starts with “A is for Army, B is for Brotherhood” — and injects a snappy phrase with every letter, like, “Love your Army.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Damien Cave
title: U.S. Defense Chief Vows to Continue Military Actions Near China
description: He said “risky intercepts” by Chinese planes in international airspace would not deter the United States and allies from patrolling, and he restated U.S. support for Taiwan.
content: The United States military will keep passing through Asian skies and seas where China has become increasingly pugnacious, the Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said in Singapore, where the Chinese defense minister’s refusal to hold talks with him has highlighted the rifts between Beijing and Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: What’s the Best Way to Treat a Workout Injury: Heat or Ice?
description: Sports physicians have long recommended the R.I.C.E. method — rest, ice, compression, elevation — for muscle injuries, but guidance is changing.
content: The prevailing theory on how to treat sprains and strains, especially from exercise, has been to follow the R.I.C.E. sequence — rest, ice, compression and elevation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, May 27-June 2
description: Did you reach the highest level, or were you at sea?
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Judge Finds Tennessee Law Aimed at Restricting Drag Shows Unconstitutional
description: The law, one of the first aimed at curbing drag performances in front of children, had been on hold for nearly two months as the legal battle went on.
content: A federal judge said late Friday that a law in Tennessee aimed at restricting drag shows was unconstitutional, saying it was overly broad and violated the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: He’s the Biggest Power Broker in Canada Whom You’ve Never Heard Of
description: This week, the government announced a new clerk of the Privy Council, an unsung role that is one of the most important in the federal government.
content: Throughout the history of the Canadian government, few jobs have been as little publicized as the clerk of the Privy Council, soon to be filled by the recently appointed John Hannaford, a senior public servant and former diplomat. While most Canadians would be hard pressed to define his new job, Mr. Hannaford is not to be underestimated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Kevin McCarthy Has a Rare Quality for a Republican House Speaker
description: He actually seem to care about the institution he leads.
content: Among the various reassessments of Kevin McCarthy following his successful debt ceiling negotiations, the one with the widest implications belongs to Matthew Continetti, who writes in The Washington Free Beacon that “McCarthy’s superpower is his desire to be speaker. He likes and wants his job.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Kaija Saariaho: 11 Essential Works
description: This poetic composer, who died on Friday, wrote indelible, simmering operas, concertos, orchestral explosions, choral meditations and solos.
content: Kaija Saariaho, the poetic and powerful composer who died on Friday at 70, was also subtle and suggestive with words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Anderson
title: Tim Robinson and the Golden Age of Cringe Comedy
description: His sketch show, “I Think You Should Leave,” zeroes in on the panic-inducing feelings of living in a society where we can’t agree on the rules.
content: Tim Robinson loves spicy food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris and Claire Cain Miller
title: What It’s Like to Be a Queer Teenager in America Today
description: Social acceptance among young people has increased significantly in only a decade. But the mental health of L.G.B.T.Q. teens is suffering.
content: Social acceptance among young people has increased significantly in only a decade. But the mental health of L.G.B.T.Q. teens is suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: India’s Worst Train Crash in Decades Kills Hundreds
description: Rescuers searched for victims at the crash site, where two passenger trains and a freight train were involved in what a government report called a “three-way accident.”
content: Rescuers searched for victims at the crash site, where two passenger trains and a freight train were involved in what a government report called a “three-way accident.”
source.name: The New York Times
